Arriving In... Style?.name: Arriving In... Style?
Arriving In... Style?.text:
Reaching journey’s end — the Arrival phase — will see the Characters looking for a bed, a drink, and the next step in their adventure, though not necessarily in that order. Be sure to describe in reasonable detail what the party sees as they arrive — are there towering gates, barred shut, or wide open fields of wheat with cottages nestled neatly between? How are the locals — warm and welcoming, or gruff and suspicious? Such details will help Characters get a feel for the location, and will help set their expectations.

Consider the Characters’ actions and the Encounters they experienced — did word travel ahead of them of their deeds, or misdeeds, on the road?

Characters who arrive at their destination suffering from a Fatigued Condition are likely in a sorry state, and need to clean themselves up or suffer a penalty to Fellowship Tests due to their scruffy appearance. This penalty is dependent on the Character’s Status. Gold Status Characters suffer a −20 penalty to Fellowship Tests and Silver a −10. Brass Status Characters suffer no penalty at all — scruffiness is expected of them.

As the length of a Stage is somewhat abstracted, any diseases contracted on the road that have an incubation period, such as the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-eis.items.R4qQc4fnxQzuNg9l]{Common Cold} or @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.BC4QyBeYAiw8cRuM]{Packer's Pox}, become full-blown outbreaks during the Arrival phase.

Characters are likely to arrive at their destination in need of supplies and services. Performing an Average (+20) Lore (region) Test reveals the best place to find these, or the Characters may ask around and hope for the best. A successful Challenging (+0) Gossip Test lets a Character know a little about current affairs, and this may be a good time to drop in some of the rumours outlined in @UUID[JournalEntry.mbXVJGCGSm8m7ANd.JournalEntryPage.LwuezrkCidrmlovt]{Rumours (Chapter 1)} and @UUID[JournalEntry.MB5a0zBGJcZhEYUI.JournalEntryPage.BYIYCOy1Yvf8irO8]{Rumours (Chapter 6)}.

Just as the Characters form an opinion of their destination, news of the Characters’ arrival often leads to local rumours and gossip. Depending on how they arrived — in a fine carriage, after a disagreement at the city gate, or unannounced in the dead of night — they may find that many have already made up their minds about their nature and intent. 

Reaching their destination should be a satisfying moment for the Characters, having put the dangers of the road behind them for a time, but it is also a good moment to subvert their expectations. Perhaps their destination, reputedly safe, has fallen under the sway of a local criminal or an enemy of the Characters. Perhaps they catch a glimpse of someone watching them, almost as if expecting their arrival. Alternatively, if you’re feeling generous, a friend made upon the road is awaiting them, a cozy table by the fire reserved in a nearby inn.

Whatever the case, the Characters are now ready to resume their adventures — or, after a short rest, set out on the next leg of their journey.

Travel Endeavours.name: Travel Endeavours
Travel Endeavours.text:
As the Characters travel the Empire’s roads, they will find themselves with a surprising amount of time on their hands. Whether in the back of a coach, around a campfire, or waiting for their dawdling, short-legged companions, each Character has one Endeavour per Stage of their journey.

Travel Endeavours represent continued action over an entire Stage of a journey, meaning that even if they are performed correctly, they are still tiring. If a Character fails a Test during an Endeavour they receive a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition.

Whilst most of these Endeavours can be attempted by anyone, some are better suited to a particular Class or Career. Additionally, at the GM’s discretion, @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.gLDW6JBuoYuzCoya.JournalEntryPage.BpwePtm5CHEfnexN]{Endeavours} found in Core may be performed during a journey.

It is up to the Characters to decide in what order they perform their Travel Endeavours. 

Earning A Living On The Road

The @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.gLDW6JBuoYuzCoya.JournalEntryPage.JX9ifRlgzzGrU2zh]{Income} Endeavour isn’t suitable for most Careers whilst on the road, but there are some Careers — from travelling judges, bailiffs, and nuns, to hunters, scouts, and coachmen — where a journey is the perfect time to pursue their craft!

Destinations And Directions.name: Destinations And Directions
Destinations And Directions.text:
Before setting off on a journey, the Characters must determine where they are going or, at least, what direction they are going in. If the Characters have a map of the location, they should have a reasonable idea of where they're headed and how long it will take, though maps of the Empire are notoriously inaccurate. Without a map, the Characters are reliant on directions from others — perhaps making Gossip Tests whenever they stop in a coaching inn — and on the even-more-unreliable road signs that dot the landscape.

  1. Determine Number of @UUID[.bEWagjEVOOEvKKmi]{Stages}

  2. GM Rolls for @UUID[.WHkF67bhn4ZHktqe#weather]{Weather}

  3. Decide @UUID[.uh8APUZK8qd74nUN]{Travel Endeavours} 

  4. Roll for @UUID[.jdxAPcL5T8JUoRyW]{Travel Encounters} (then repeat 2.)

  5. @UUID[.mcrUfZwUxzc23IA2]{Arrival phase}, if this was the final stage.

How Far is it to…?

As previously mentioned, maps of the Empire are notoriously inaccurate, few feature any indication of scale, and many cartographers have found their efforts to improve matters entirely unwelcome. Naturally, no noble likes to be told that their ancestral holdings are a hundred square miles smaller than they had supposed.

When calculating travel distances, it is best to bear these inaccuracies in mind. A journey between neighbouring settlements usually consists of a single Stage. Longer journeys between important cities take between 2 and 4 Stages. Any journey longer than this should be broken up into multiple legs, with stops to rest, resupply, and introduce new adventures to the Characters. If your group enjoys a more involved travel experience, increase the number of Stages by 2 or more.

For example, Bögenhafen to Middenheim might instead be Bögenhafen to Altdorf, and then Altdorf to Middenheim.

Travel Stages.name: Travel Stages
Travel Stages.text:
A journey is divided into a number of Travel Stages. The number of Stages is up to GM discretion, with longer journeys having more Stages. The GM should feel free to adjust the number of Stages based on the Players’ preferences. For some groups, detailed journeys with a plethora of random encounters and challenges can become an exciting, memorable part of their Character’s adventure. For other groups, a brief description of the journey with one or two complications to add some spice is more than enough.

Once the number of Stages is determined, it is modified by the lowest Movement among the Characters, whether on foot, mounted, or in a vehicle. If this is 3 or less, the journey should be increased by 1–2 stages. If the Characters are all lucky enough to possess mounts with a Movement of 6 or more, the total number of Stages is halved to a minimum of 1.

Characters may attempt to reduce this number further with a Challenging (+0) Navigation or a Lore Test. The Test must be relevant to the location, such as Lore (Reikland). Having a proper map of the route makes the Test Average (+20). A success reduces the number of Stages by 1, to a minimum of 1.

Example: Everyone wants to go from Altdorf to Middenheim. Gunnar and Molrella are slower, and they can’t wait that long, so they decide to get mounts. Salundra makes a Lore (Reikland) Test and succeeds, so they go even faster. The GM decides that the journey from Altdorf to Middenheim is quite far, and consists of 4 Stages. Thanks to the mounts, no one has a Movement of 3 or less. Salundra’s excellent navigation reduces the number of stages by 1, for a total of 3 Stages — an arduous trek indeed!

On The Road Again.name: On The Road Again
On The Road Again.text:
Securing food and shelter are among the most mundane difficulties of the road. To those with the means, both are reasonably accessible on the Empire’s more travelled routes. Where available, inns and hostels provide bread and board to those with money. Alternatively, Characters may stock up with their own supplies before setting out. You can find the costs of travel goods, food, and lodging in Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay. Characters and their mounts consume 1 Encumbrance of food daily, at a cost of 2/–, but this may be supplemented by characters using the @UUID[JournalEntry.1tdhntCNqK83TS94.JournalEntryPage.DWosXgF1vKBGbD2f]{Forage} Endeavour, below. Additionally, food not properly stored, or kept for too long, may spoil, putting Characters at risk of contracting the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.txeLd7R13qxSvmsr]{Galloping Trots}.

Weather

Bad weather is the greatest enemy of travellers (other than actual enemies of travellers, particularly those armed with blunderbusses, crossbows, and loose morals). The GM should roll for @Table[weather]{Weather} at the beginning of each Stage.

Adverse weather conditions can turn any normal encounter into a nightmare. The following table can be used for the Reikland and similarly temperate climates. For weather further north of the Reikland, add between +10 and +30 to the result, and for weather further south, subtract between −10 and −30.

Dry

Prolonged dry weather causes curtains of dust to blow across the road at the slightest breeze, obscuring vision and parching throats. Travel is easy, if uncomfortable, but @UUID[.DWosXgF1vKBGbD2f]{Forage} Endeavours are at a −10 as the weather makes finding water harder.

Fair

For once, the weather is being kind. There are no weather-related hazards.

Rain

Rain can last anywhere from a few hours to a few days. The ‘spring showers’ so beloved of poets can sometimes last up to a week, proving that poets spend remarkably little time outdoors away from wine and warmth. Rain reduces visibility to 75 ft or less. Additionally, ranged weapons suffer a –10 penalty to use due to driving wind and rain.

Downpour

Terrible storms reduce visibility to near zero, making any sound below a shout impossible to hear and imposing a –10 penalty on all physical Tests. Everything and everyone not under cover is soaked through within minutes. Water streams off the road, carving deep gullies so that the road is churned to little more than a bog. Ranged weapons suffer a –20 penalty to use due to the terrible weather, and exposed gunpowder is immediately ruined. Animals with the Skittish Trait may also become spooked by sudden jolts of lightning during bad storms.

Snow

A gentle snow covers the world in a blanket of white, making everything seem new and clean. It is undoubtedly beautiful, until one has to move through it. Snow reduces visibility to 150 ft, and makes movement faster than Walking impossible. Characters travelling in Snow must make an Average (+20) Endurance Test or gain a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition.

Blizzard

Snow turns everything into a sightless white hell. The road disappears beneath a fast-accumulating blanket of snow, leaving only trees to steer by. Visibility is close to zero. Movement faster than Walking is impossible. Ranged weapons are useless in these conditions. Characters travelling in a Blizzard must make a Challenging (+0) Endurance Test or gain a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition.

Options: Catching a Cold

At the end of every Stage, any Character exposed to Rain or Snow without both a good coat and a tent or other shelter must Test for @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.WCivInLZrqEtZzF4#exposure]{Exposure}. Characters exposed to a Downpour or Blizzard must Test even if they have both a coat and tent, though lacking either of these makes this test Difficult (-10), while lacking both makes it Hard (-20). The effects of Exposure remain until the Character has warmed up at a suitable, sheltered location.

In Winter or Spring, any character who suffered from Exposure during any Stage of their journey also contracts the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-eis.items.R4qQc4fnxQzuNg9l]{Common Cold}, the effects of which manifest during the @UUID[.mcrUfZwUxzc23IA2]{Arrival Phase}.

Encounters.name: Encounters
Encounters.text:
Travel in the Old World can be many things, but rarely is it predictable. Paranoid road wardens, intrepid merchants, and dutiful pilgrims throng the highways of the Empire, whilst less beaten tracks are home to roving bands of mutants, unsanctioned toll roads, and watchful bandits. The Characters may experience such events more or less at random, but all Encounters should add either to the flavour of the world, or to the themes and narrative of the current story.

Positive Encounters

@Table[positiveenc]{Positive Encounters} are generally beneficial to your party, though many groups find a way to turn any situation against them! Positive Encounters may be triggered by an Impressive success or better on a Travel Endeavour, or simply if you wish to reward the Characters for being particularly clever or well prepared.

Coincidental Encounters

@Table[coincidentalenc]{Coincidental Encounters} are neither harmful nor beneficial to the Character, they are simply the sort of thing travellers in the Old World run into as a matter of course. These Encounters can be used if the Characters have rolled neither an Impressive success or failure on a @UUID[.uh8APUZK8qd74nUN]{Travel Endeavour} or simply because the GM wishes to add some local colour.

Harmful Encounters

@Table[harmfulenc] The Empire is fraught with danger, and an unwary or simply unlucky traveller can fall afoul of any number of hazards. Should one of the Characters fumble a @UUID[.uh8APUZK8qd74nUN]{Travel Endeavour}, or the majority of characters fail in their Travel Endeavours, any of the misadventures below may befall them. 

These charts are entirely optional, and the results advisory. They should be used to add some unpredictability to a journey, but if you, as the GM, are uncomfortable or unsure on how to proceed, feel free to pick a different Encounter, or none at all.

While every group is different, it is rarely advisable to have more than one Encounter occurring during any Stage of a journey.

Where's My Random Encounter Table?

You will notice that there are few Encounters that specifically say the characters become embroiled in combat without other options being available. This is an intentional choice. Whilst the threat of violence is an inescapable part of life on the roads in the Old World, repeated random encounters do little to advance the story or add much to the Characters’ own narratives. They come with the burden of having to improvise an unplanned Encounter. We recommend the GM should instead consider the current state of the adventure and the nature and means of the Characters’ antagonists before deciding if an attack on the road will advance the game. If the Characters are being pursued by bandits, cults, or other nefarious beings, or if they are travelling to investigate word of Goblins or Beastmen, it may make perfect sense. If they are simply travelling to the next town over to pursue a story hook, consider presenting them with difficulties other than combat.

Travel.name: Travel
Travel.text:
The sheer scale of the Empire, and the world beyond, means that travel is a necessary part of life for transient Characters. One of the main differences between the Characters and run-of-the-mill citizens of the Empire is that they lack roots that force them to stay in one place. This freedom comes with dire complications: the Empire's roads, whilst being the veins of commerce, are infested with bandits; the forests look dark, full of the braying of Beastmen and the cries of Goblins; the looming mountains are crawling with Orcs and worse…

Travel often fills the gaps between adventures, and can provide an opportunity to engage in other activities similar to the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.gLDW6JBuoYuzCoya]{Between Adventures} chapter. Other times, travelling is the adventure itself. Regardless of when it occurs, this chapter provides tools to tell dramatic tales while on the road.

To begin, the Characters must determine their destination or direction. With a destination in mind, the GM can determine how long the journey will take, dividing the travel time into Stages. During each Stage of a journey, the GM rolls for the @Table[weather]{Weather}, the Characters may engage in @UUID[.uh8APUZK8qd74nUN]{Travel Endeavours}, and any @UUID[.jdxAPcL5T8JUoRyW]{Travel Events} that take place are resolved. The @UUID[.mcrUfZwUxzc23IA2]{Arrival Phase} occurs as the characters reach their destination — hopefully not too much worse for wear.

options: It's All Optional, Again

Just like the Between Adventures chapter, all of these tools are optional and intended to expand the rules presented on @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.dT0qi7Hq6PKbAoAu.JournalEntryPage.iqWcd5vPHZTHT5jh#travel]{Travel}. You may choose to roleplay more of your travel, whilst using these rules to flesh those scenes out. It's all up to you!

Forage.name: Forage
Forage.text: It is often impossible to carry all the food and water needed for a long journey, and resupplying as the journey continues can become prohibitively expensive. Most travellers supplement their rations with food and water gathered from the land, whether by hunting, trapping, or foraging. Perform an Outdoor Survival Test, as directed by the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.6zOdTLv3YeYeJ4hR.JournalEntryPage.cFqWFER60SjM5Wn3]{skill}, taking note of the Gathering Food and Herbs optional rule.

Gather Information.name: Gather Information
Gather Information.text:
Whilst the Empire does have a messenger corps, most news moves via word of mouth. A Character can choose to spend their time gossiping for news, and asking questions in coaching inns, if the route has enough traffic to allow it. Perform a Challenging (+0) Gossip Test, and ask the GM as many questions as SL scored, which the GM must answer as truthfully as the people in that part of the world would know. Alternatively, the Character may wish to hear what rumours are currently circulating. See @UUID[JournalEntry.mbXVJGCGSm8m7ANd.JournalEntryPage.LwuezrkCidrmlovt]{Rumours} for a selection of rumours circulating in the Empire.

Improvised Answers

A Character may wish to gather information about a topic that you, as the GM, have no clue about, as it hasn’t been prepared, or is too obscure. In these instances, feel free to make up any answer you wish, regardless of how outlandish, though any questioning Character should know that the NPC is simply making up what they think might be true, without any basis in reality. If the NPC might be inclined to conceal this fact, an Intuition Test may be called for.

Keep Watch.name: Keep Watch
Keep Watch.text: Whilst any traveller in the Empire worth their salt retains an awareness of their surroundings, you forgo other activities to remain vigilant at all times — sleeping less, not engaging in idle chatter, scouting ahead, and so on. With a successful Challenging (+0) Perception Test, the Characters may not be @Condition[Surprised] during that stage of their journey.

Make Camp.name: Make Camp
Make Camp.text: Often travellers will focus too much on the destination, and not enough on the journey itself; upon arrival they are haggard, exhausted, and ill-prepared for what they are about to face. Anyone can pitch a tent or unfurl a bedroll. Seasoned travellers, however, take the time to make themselves comfortable at night — choosing a good location, gathering firewood, preparing water, and so on. Perform a Challenging (+0) Outdoor Survival Test or a Challenging (+0) Heal Test. Each SL from either Test may be spent to remove SL @Condition[Fatigued] Conditions from a Character, or @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.WCivInLZrqEtZzF4#healing]{heal a Character}.

Map the Route.name: Map the Route
Map the Route.text:
Often the long hours on the road are tedium for academic types, who are otherwise unsuited to the physical tasks of travel. However, future travelling can be made significantly easier by creating a map, and with sufficient materials — paper, quills, and ink — such an effort is possible. To create a map of the route, a Character must begin an Extended Trade (Cartography) or Art (Drawing) Test, with a required number of SL equal to twice the number of Stages in the journey. This Test may be continued every time this Endeavour is undertaken.

A proper map of a region makes any Lore or Navigation Tests when setting out on a journey Average (+20), rather than Challenging (+0) (@UUID[JournalEntry.1tdhntCNqK83TS94.JournalEntryPage.bEWagjEVOOEvKKmi]{Travel Stages}). Maps may fetch anywhere from 1/– for poorly scratched lines, all the way to tens or hundreds of Crowns for particularly fine works of art, (though these are unlikely to be completed whilst travelling).

Practice a Skill.name: Practice a Skill
Practice a Skill.text: The monotony of travel represents the perfect time for many Characters to practise their Skills for their coming trials. A Character may perform a Challenging (+0) Test against a single Skill that would be possible to practise whilst travelling — Navigation, Trade (Herbalism), Language (Wastelander), and so on. Success means that the Character may reverse the result of one Test using that Skill during the following adventure, or any subsequent Stages of travel.

Recuperate.name: Recuperate
Recuperate.text: Travel is generally inimical to rest: hiking through forests and over mountain paths, sleeping under the stars in biting cold and burning heat, and hiding from monsters and other terrible threats. These are not situations often prescribed by attending physicians. However, you have made special efforts to ensure you do not overly exert yourself. You may count this Stage as if it were ‘taking it easy’ for the purposes of @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.WCivInLZrqEtZzF4#healing-wounds]{Healing Wounds}. You may not choose this Endeavour if, for any reason, you suffered a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition during this Stage of the journey.

Woodcraft.name: Woodcraft
Woodcraft.text: Through a canny understanding of the land and a good nose for the weather, you may alleviate the worst of any harsh weather you encounter. Attempt a Challenging (+0) Outdoor Survival Test, modified by –10 per step the weather is away from Fair. On a success, you and your companions do not need to Test for Exposure due to inclement weather.

Mistaken Identity.name: Confusión de identidades
Mistaken Identity.text:
Los héroes se encuentran con una banda de mutantes medio muertos de hambre que se han trasladado hace poco a esta zona. La voraz banda la lidera Knud Cratinx, un antiguo ladrón de ovejas que hace poco ha empezado a mostrar la marca del Caos en forma de escamas en la piel. Knud y sus compañeros mutantes han asaltado una diligencia de las Cuatro Estaciones que se dirigía a Altdorf y están masacrando a los ocupantes. Durante este encuentro, los Personajes descubren el cuerpo de Kastor Lieberung (ver @UUID[JournalEntry.bmJLqIQGcb0sIinQ.JournalEntryPage.aawH7wAMaFsy17L8#la-trama]{La Trama}) y, sin darse cuenta, se ven atrapados en una red que el Caos está extendiendo por todo el Imperio. Un PJ (a ser posible, con una Carrera de Pícaro) reconoce a un viejo conocido al que ha mutado el Caos, un recordatorio de que la mácula de los Poderes Ruinosos es una amenaza permanente de la que nadie está a salvo.

Sangre en la carretera

Un par de horas después de que la diligencia llegue a la carretera principal, toma una curva y se encuentra con un espectáculo espeluznante. Hay una figura humana agazapada en el camino, de espaldas al vehículo, inclinada sobre el cuerpo de un cochero de la compañía Cuatro Estaciones. La figura se da la vuelta y los Personajes ven una mano cortada colgando de su asquerosa boca. La criatura es reconocible como humana, pero la carne cuelga en jirones de su cara y manos, y un ícor verde rezuma de sus ojos. Escupiendo la mano, se precipita hacia vuestra diligencia blandiendo una daga ensangrentada.

Ayuda 2: Rolf Hurtsis

La figura que se precipita como un poseso hacia vosotros te resulta familiar. De repente, caes en la cuenta. Debajo de la carne podrida y el icor goteante, reconoces el rostro de Rolf Hurtsis, un ladrón y viejo amigo. De jóvenes, corristeis muchas aventuras juntos, pero está cambiado de forma horrible. Hará cosa de un año que a Rolf le salió un extraño sarpullido.

Cambió y se volvió más irritable e incluso violento a veces. Para ocultar este mal de la piel, se hizo una capucha con un viejo saco, pero esto le dificultaba la visión y no podía escapar de la Guardia cuando un trabajo salía mal. Lo último que supiste de él fue que escapó de una celda y desapareció sin dejar rastro... hasta ahora.

Un personaje Pícaro (o, en su defecto, un personaje de nivel Bronce como un Burgués, Académico u otro personaje urbano) se da cuenta, con gran sorpresa, de que este Mutante es Rolf Hurtsis, un compañero ladrón y viejo amigo de su ciudad natal. Entrega al jugador la @UUID[JournalEntry.fCNnElQzxwEOeJWJ.JournalEntryPage.5HgA2hCdXI8XfK4C]{Ayuda de Juego 2: Rolf Hurtsis}.

Cuando Rolf corre hacia el carruaje, los caballos se asustan y salen disparados, rompiendo los arneses al hacerlo. Hultz, que sujetaba las riendas, es arrastrado tras ellos. Gunnar lucha por accionar los frenos y evitar que el carruaje se estrelle contra los árboles. Lo consigue, pero luego se queda paralizado por el miedo cuando Rolf salta hacia él. Depende de los aventureros salvar la situación. Si no hacen nada, Gunnar gana el Estado @Condition[Sorprendido], por lo que no podrá defenderse del horrible Mutante hasta el siguiente asalto. Los pasajeros del carruaje no harán nada a menos que se vean en peligro. Si Phillipe sigue presente, acudirá en ayuda de los aventureros, usando su espada en lugar de su pistola por miedo a herir a un aliado. Es un luchador competente y sabrá identificar a los personajes más débiles para ayudarlos a defenderse. Marie permanecerá en el carruaje para proteger a su señora, y solo se alejará del lado de Lady Isolde si considera que es la mejor forma de proteger a su protegida de cualquier amenaza.

Cuando los personajes tengan la oportunidad de inspeccionar el cuerpo mutilado del cochero de Cuatro Estaciones, verán que una saeta de ballesta en el cuello fue la causa de su muerte. El cochero lleva una cota de malla con mangas, que puede usar cualquier personaje humano de complexión media. Las huellas de su carruaje continúan por el camino, alejándose de los aventureros y desapareciendo tras una curva.

OPCIONES: ¿QUÉ…? ¿NO HAY MUTANTES?

Si los jugadores están esperando enfrentarse a Mutantes, puede que quieras sorprenderlos con un encuentro diferente. Por el bien de la historia de la campaña, los personajes deben encontrar el cuerpo de Kastor Lieberung y las dos cartas que llevaba encima: cómo sucede esto no es importante. Incluso si esta es la primera vez que los jugadores se enfrentan a esta aventura, las siguientes alternativas al ataque de los Mutantes pueden servirte de inspiración.

Una investigación oficial

Cuando el grupo llega al lugar del carruaje destrozado, dos patrulleros del camino ya están allí. Detienen el carruaje de los aventureros y exigen ayuda para cargar los cuerpos de las víctimas en un carro. Los cadáveres serán llevados al pueblo más cercano para su entierro, mientras que los cuerpos de tres mutantes muertos en el ataque serán quemados en el lugar, usando los restos del carruaje como leña.

Mientras ayudan a los patrulleros, los personajes pueden tener la oportunidad de saquear un par de cuerpos sin ser vistos: lo que encuentren depende de ti. Al descubrir el cuerpo de Kastor Lieberung y notar su parecido con uno de los personajes jugadores, pueden fingir ser familiares y pedir llevarse el cuerpo y sus pertenencias. A tu discreción, un uso exitoso de Encanto o Soborno garantizará el éxito. Por supuesto, ahora los personajes tienen un cadáver del que preocuparse, y Lady Isolde no permitirá bajo ninguna circunstancia que lo suban al carruaje.

Si los jugadores están molesta y excesivamente confiados ante la emboscada esperada, puedes darles un giro a las cosas describiendo de forma ambigua la primera impresión del lugar. Los patrulleros no llevan uniformes evidentes y sus insignias no son visibles mientras dirigen a un grupo andrajoso de jornaleros que pasaban por allí en un carro lleno de estiércol: mientras se mueven entre los cuerpos, es difícil decir si están investigando o saqueando; su ropa sucia y desgastada, los rostros llenos de mugre y sus posturas encorvadas podrían parecer, a primera vista, signos de mutaciones menores; y puede que uno o más estén masticando algo mientras se agachan sobre los cuerpos, con empanadas ocultas en sus manos, y miran fijamente al grupo cuando llegan a la escena.

Con un poco de imaginación, podrías convencer a jugadores demasiado impulsivos de que se enfrentan a Mutantes, y podrían meterse en serios problemas si atacan a patrulleros que simplemente están cumpliendo con su deber.

Bandidos

Como se menciona en @UUID[JournalEntry.mbXVJGCGSm8m7ANd.JournalEntryPage.7rA5Koj7kOMuwTH1#problemas-con-los-bandidos]{Opciones: Buscando una trampa}, el personal de la posada El Cochero y los Caballos podría estar actuando como vigías para una banda de bandidos. En lugar de Mutantes, los personajes se encuentran con Forajidos saqueando el carruaje destrozado, pero por lo demás, el capítulo continúa sin cambios.

¿Te conozco?

En lugar de encontrar el cuerpo de Kastor Lieberung, los aventureros podrían encontrarse con él en persona, acompañado de un puñado de otros cultistas.

Es un sacerdote del culto en la carrera de @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-eis.items.BoF0SgCc7ldSFc79]{Magus del Culto}. Su magia le permitió a él y a sus compañeros derrotar a los Mutantes que atacaron su carruaje, pero este igualmente ha quedado destrozado, Lieberung y varios de sus acompañantes están heridos, y detienen el carruaje de los aventureros suplicando que los lleven.

Cuando son rechazados —y @UUID[Actor.goVesadmHWsl5E98]{Lady Isolde} seguramente insistirá en que esos andrajosos y ensangrentados maleantes se alejen de su carruaje—, atacan. Aunque debes asegurarte de que Lieberung muera en el combate que sigue, los aventureros y todos los presentes tienen tiempo de sobra para notar el gran parecido entre él y uno de los personajes.

Los hombres rata

Los Skaven son una parte importante de la campaña El Enemigo Interior a partir de Muerte en el Reik. Si deseas introducir a estos sigilosos hombres rata antes de tiempo, tienes aquí una oportunidad perfecta.

Además de los documentos relacionados con su supuesta herencia, Lieberung transportaba un fragmento de piedra bruja en una caja forrada de plomo. Un grupo de Skaven lo siguió desde Middenheim, con la intención de robar la piedra para ellos. Los personajes llegan justo a tiempo para ver caer a Lieberung y a un grupo de figuras encorvadas y encapuchadas desaparecer en el bosque con un pequeño cofre.

No hay razón para alarmarse

Todo está en calma cuando los personajes llegan. Los atacantes ya se han ido y en el bosque cercano no se escucha nada más que la fauna salvaje.

Por supuesto, los jugadores no lo saben, y si están esperando un ataque de Mutantes en cualquier momento, puedes divertirte manteniendo todo en silencio y permitiendo que los jugadores se enreden en una paranoia creciente ante un ataque que nunca llegará. El crujido de una rama al caer; el susurro de una criatura pequeña entre los matorrales; una ráfaga de viento entre las hojas... todo puede hacer saltar los nervios de un grupo ya tenso, especialmente si sufrieron heridas en un encuentro anterior y temen estar demasiado débiles para enfrentar a un enemigo serio.

The Inn of the Seven Spokes.name: La posada Los Siete Radios
The Inn of the Seven Spokes.text:
La casa de postas Los Siete Radios presenta una disposición muy similar a la de La Diligencia y los Caballos. Tres diligencias se hospedan allí por la noche, por lo que la posada está abarrotada. Será una parada tranquila, a menos que los Personajes decidan interactuar con los demás clientes. Ninguno de ellos resulta especialmente interesante… a menos que tú decidas lo contrario. Cualquier PNJ puede revelar alguno de los rumores disponibles, pero, en general, este debería ser un lugar tranquilo para pasar la noche, y el viaje debería continuar sin problemas a la mañana siguiente. Como ya es costumbre, los cocheros beben en exceso —quizá incluso más que en noches anteriores, considerando el día que acaban de pasar— y es probable que estén igual de resacosos al amanecer.

At the inn, @UUID[Actor.goVesadmHWsl5E98]{Lady Isolde}, @UUID[Actor.s3C4siPuECgh14Vl]{Janna}, and @UUID[Actor.LBc3rDFHm6j2rI6C]{Marie} abandonan la diligencia y reservan asientos en una diligencia de Cuatro Estaciones, que parte hacia la capital a la mañana siguiente. Los Personajes también pueden decidir bajarse y buscar otro medio de transporte, si así lo desean.

El resto del viaje hacia Altdorf transcurre sin incidentes, aunque puedes aprovechar para introducir nuevos @UUID[JournalEntry.MB5a0zBGJcZhEYUI.JournalEntryPage.BYIYCOy1Yvf8irO8]{rumores} o añadir algo de color con encuentros menores: un destacamento de caballería estatal, un vendedor ambulante con un carro bien surtido, o algún otro detalle que te parezca interesante.

La física fortuita

Puede que uno o más PJs resulten heridos tras el encuentro con los mutantes, y sería una suerte que hubiera un físico en Los Siete Radios. Por una vez, Ranald sonríe a nuestros héroes: la doktora @UUID[Actor.1KyqwFkCeyOkJ3l7]{Anida Pflaster} happens to be at the inn. se encuentra en la posada. La mujer está disfrutando de una bebida en el bar mientras el cochero cambia de caballos y atenderá a los heridos por @Pay[4cp]{4cp} por PJ. La buena doktora o alguien como ella pueden encontrarse en casi cualquier lugar durante esta aventura u otras si los Personajes tienen una gran necesidad y te sientes misericordioso. Estos servicios nunca son gratuitos, por supuesto, y los Jugadores no deben acabar con una falsa sensación de seguridad por tener encuentros con físicos demasiado frecuentes y convenientes. Pero, una o dos veces, tal encuentro puede resultar un salvavidas, literalmente.

@UUID[Actor.1KyqwFkCeyOkJ3l7]{Anida Pflaster}

Resolution.name: Resolución
Resolution.text:
Aparte de los puntos que des al final de la sesión por una buena interpretación e ideas inteligentes, deberías conceder PX por lo siguiente:

  • @Exp[10,Rolf Hurtsis ha sido derrotado]{10 puntos por derrotar a Rolf Hurtsis}

  • @Exp[20,Los Mutantes han sido derrotados]{20 puntos a cada uno por derrotar a los mutantes}

  • @Exp[10,Carta de herencia encontrada]{10 puntos a cada uno por encontrar la carta sobre la herencia}

  • @Exp[5,No levantar sospechas entre los guardas]{5 puntos a cada uno por no levantar sospechas entre los guardas de caminos}

Como siempre, eres libre de premiar con PX por cualquier otra cosa que creas que lo merezca, usando las cantidades anteriores como guía.

The Mayhem Mystery Tour.name: La gira del misterio caótico
The Mayhem Mystery Tour.text:
Al girar la curva o al avanzar sigilosamente por el bosque, los Personajes se encuentran con una escena espantosa. Un carruaje volcado bloquea el camino, y varios cadáveres están esparcidos por el suelo a su alrededor. Dos de los caballos intentan desesperadamente liberarse de los arneses mientras una criatura con un cuerpo grande y una cabeza increíblemente pequeña los golpea de forma maníaca con un hacha.

Un @UUID[Actor.cKp4JV3XNZ5l67eM]{Humano} con cabeza de perro yace junto al carruaje, gritando. La sangre brota de su pierna herida mientras otro @UUID[Actor.CC24r6wLC9Gce4GL]{Murante} con la cabeza puntiaguda intenta vendarle la herida. Un cuarto @UUID[Actor.50xLTGTs9Cq2VrGF]{Mutante}, con pies hendidos, devora uno de los cadáveres. Registrando los cuerpos hay un humano de piel escamosa que sostiene una ballesta cargada. Este es @UUID[Actor.7mUvNXJrBedMDmrg]{Knud Cratinx}, el líder de los Mutantes.

Si los Personajes atacan, los Mutantes, que no prestan atención a su entorno, reciben el Estado @Condition[Sorprendido]. Si los Personajes optan solo por el combate a distancia, los Mutantes confusos reciben el Estado de @Condition[Sorprendido] durante dos asaltos, lo que permite a los Personajes disparar durante dos asaltos antes de que los Mutantes reaccionen. Luego, los Mutantes cargan al combate mientras Knud se mantiene atrás disparando con su ballesta. Una vez que dos Mutantes son eliminados, los demás huyen al bosque. Su rastro puede seguirse durante media milla antes de perderse; ningún esfuerzo posterior permite retomarlo. Si los Personajes entran en el bosque, haz que se sientan inquietos describiendo crujidos extraños en la maleza, formas oscuras que parecen acechar en los bordes de su visión, y la total ausencia de sonidos de animales o insectos. Por ahora están a salvo, pero no deberían saberlo.

Los cadáveres que rodean al carruaje volcado son los de su otro cochero, un par de artesanos, un iniciado de Sigmar y un jornalero. El cochero aún lleva puesta su cota de malla de mangas, y junto a su cuerpo están su trabuco y la munición. Ninguno de los otros cuerpos tiene objetos de valor, ya que Knud se ha apoderado de todo. Si Knud es abatido y registrado, los Personajes encuentran @Pay[2co3cp13pb]{2 co, 3, cp y 13 pb}, un anillo valorado en 3 co,y un relicario de plata valorado en 1 co con un retrato en miniatura de uno de los artesanos muertos. Todos estos objetos están detallados en el equipo de @UUID[Actor.7mUvNXJrBedMDmrg]{Knud}.

@UUID[Actor.qULdvMqcLZgULyCX]{Rolf Hurtsis}

@UUID[Actor.IdVTzDu27riIsWKq]{Terenz}, @UUID[Actor.cKp4JV3XNZ5l67eM]{Mikael}, @UUID[Actor.CC24r6wLC9Gce4GL]{Johann}, @UUID[Actor.50xLTGTs9Cq2VrGF]{Erik}, - Bandidos Mutantes

@UUID[Actor.7mUvNXJrBedMDmrg]{Knud Cratinx}

El Doble

Mientras los Personajes inspeccionan la escena de la emboscada o persiguen a los Mutantes dentro del bosque, notan otro cuerpo tendido bajo un arbusto, algo alejado del carruaje, pero no tanto como para pasar desapercibido. El cuerpo tiene dos virotes de ballesta clavados en la espalda y viste ropas que lo identifican como un ciudadano, posiblemente un artesano. Este es el cadáver de Kastor Lieberung (ver @UUID[JournalEntry.bmJLqIQGcb0sIinQ.JournalEntryPage.aawH7wAMaFsy17L8#la-trama]{La Trama}), un cultista veterano de la Mano Púrpura. Kastor viajaba desde Middenheim hacia Bögenhafen para reclamar una herencia. Cuando el carruaje fue atacado, intentó escabullirse, pero fue abatido por dos virotes disparados por Knud.

Al girar el cadáver, los Personajes se llevarán una gran sorpresa, porque se parece exactamente a uno de ellos. Cuál de ellos es, lo decides tú. El Personaje ideal sería aquel que probablemente se vea tentado por la idea de hacerse pasar por Kastor para obtener su herencia.

Un trozo de pergamino manchado de sangre sobresale del chaquetón del cadáver. Entrega a los jugadores la @UUID[JournalEntry.fCNnElQzxwEOeJWJ.JournalEntryPage.sO0kei2vK7KHcU49]{Ayuda de Juego 3: La Herencia}. Las manchas de sangre oscurecen algunos detalles. Tras leerlo, los Personajes deberían tener muchas ganas de dirigirse a Bögenhafen para reclamar la herencia.

En un bolsillo interior hay otra carta sin manchas de sangre: @UUID[JournalEntry.fCNnElQzxwEOeJWJ.JournalEntryPage.QdZKTqUjJWh18MIH]{Ayuda de Juego 4: La Declaración Jurada}.

Ayuda de juego 3: La herencia

Bufete de los Sres. Lock, Stock y Barl

Abogados de lo Civil, Comisionados de Juramentos, etc.

Garten Weg

Bögenhafen

 

Distinguido Herr Lieberung:

 

Tras largas investigaciones, hemos llegado al convencimiento de que es usted el único pariente vivo del difunto baronet Lieberung, de la población de Ubersreik. Por consiguiente, y sin perjuicio de cualquier otro factor desconocido y pertinente hasta la fecha, se me ha encargado informarle de que es usted es el único beneficiario del testamento del difunto baronet (en lo sucesivo, la parte de la primera parte) así como de su título nobiliario y de todas las tierras y fincas vinculadas a él.

El abajo firmante, en calidad de albacea testamentario del mencionado documento de la parte de la primera parte, por la presente le exhorta a que se dirija con toda la rapidez posible a mis oficinas en la dirección que se indica en el membrete de la misma. A continuación, y tras presentar por su parte una declaración jurada firmada por dos testigos que confirme su identidad como Kastor Aloysius Lieberung, nos complacerá entregarle el título de propiedad de la mansión Lieberung y de todas las tierras y fincas vinculadas, así como la suma legada de veinte mil coronas de oro imperiales.

 

Su más humilde y respetuoso servidor,

 

Dietrich Barl. K.C., lL. B. (Alt)

Firmado el décimo día de trasbrujo del año dos mil quinientos doce del Imperio.

ayuda de juego 4: la declaración jurada

Los abajo firmantes juramos y afirmamos solemnemente que el portador de este documento es Kastor Aloysius Lieberung.

 

Ingrid Zicherman, sacerdotisa

Templo de Sigmar, Nuln

 

Oskar Helmut

Maestre del Gremio de Mercaderes, Nuln

 

Y en calidad de testigo

Julius Schwungrad, de la Excelentísima Compañía de Abogados, Nuln

OPCIONES: TÚ NO TE PARECES EN NADA A KASTOR…

En la campaña tal como está escrita, el magister impedimentae es un Humano de sexo masculino llamado Kastor Lieberung. Esto está bien, siempre que el grupo incluya a un Personaje Humano masculino. Si no es así, o si simplemente quieres cambiar la Especie y, si hace falta, el género del magister impedimentae para que coincida con un Personaje que encaje mejor, consulta la tabla que aparece más abajo.

¿Qué hay en un nombre?

La mayoría de los miembros de cultos del Caos en el Imperio son Humanos; los Halflings, Elfos y Enanos son menos comunes, pero no desconocidos. Una vez elegido el Personaje que será el doble, solo necesitas cambiar el nombre de Kastor por uno apropiado.

Deberías escoger una identidad para el magister que resulte lo más divertida y desafiante posible para uno de los Personajes. El nombre del magister ni siquiera tiene que parecerse a “Kastor Lieberung”, especialmente si tu grupo está formado por jugadores veteranos que podrían tener ciertas expectativas: puede ser cualquier nombre que decidas. Si cambias la identidad de Kastor, ten en cuenta que también deberás modificar la información en el @UUID[JournalEntry.fCNnElQzxwEOeJWJ.JournalEntryPage.sO0kei2vK7KHcU49]{Ayuda de Juego 3: La Herencia} y en el @UUID[JournalEntry.fCNnElQzxwEOeJWJ.JournalEntryPage.QdZKTqUjJWh18MIH]{Ayuda de Juego 4: La Declaración Jurada}.

La llegada de la ley

Poco después de que los Personajes inspeccionen el lugar de la emboscada, divisan jinetes que vienen desde la dirección de Altdorf. Se trata de una patrulla de cinco guardias de caminos liderados por @UUID[Actor.qV5dluDJYZGoMpl1]{Magnus Pflaster} que galopan hacia los Personajes en cuanto avistan el carruaje volcado.

Los guardas de caminos se muestran inicialmente muy suspicaces con los aventureros, que, a primera vista, podrían parecer bandidos. Exigen saber qué ha ocurrido e inspeccionan la escena con atención. Siempre que los Personajes sean educados y expliquen lo sucedido con los Mutantes, los guardias de caminos les creerán. Sin embargo, los insultos o amenazas provocarán que arresten a los Personajes y los lleven a la próxima posada para un interrogatorio detallado.

@UUID[Actor.qV5dluDJYZGoMpl1]{Magnus Pflaster}

@UUID[Actor.CwJLyqjh8U2DUEuG]{Baldwin}, @UUID[Actor.pkwa4XnIzZnvj7UV]{Leopold}, @UUID[Actor.FwWDYWJYYwTcv607]{Sunna}, @UUID[Actor.mzEIIBv3XAuas4R6]{Willirun} - Guardas de caminos

Asumiendo el control de la situación, los guardias obligan a todos los Personajes capaces de trabajar a colaborar. Por supuesto, @UUID[Actor.goVesadmHWsl5E98]{Lady Isolde} y su séquito están exentos de tal tarea, pero se espera que todos los demás ayuden. Con algo de esfuerzo y las tiradas que consideres necesarias, el carruaje volcado puede ser enderezado. Uno de los dos caballos que quedan, herido de muerte, es sacrificado con piedad, mientras que el otro se calma gracias a la presencia de los guardias y sus monturas.

Los @UUID[Actor.guaFC5d5WK8ExDhk]{caballos} del carruaje de los Personajes están pastando no muy lejos, adentrándose en el bosque. Si algún Personaje se les acerca sin tener ningún Avance en Montar (Caballo), Criar Animales o Carisma Animal, los caballos aún están nerviosos y pueden cocear. En tal caso, el Personaje debe superar un Chequeo de Esquivar para poder acercarse lo suficiente como para agarrar los restos del arnés y controlar a los animales. Si los Personajes no logran calmarlos, algunos de los guardias de caminos intervienen y logran tranquilizar a los caballos con facilidad profesional.

Los caballos recuperados se reparten entre los dos carruajes, y se realizan reparaciones improvisadas en sus arneses dañados.

Con los Personajes de nuevo en su carruaje y los cadáveres apilados en el otro, los guardias de caminos encabezan la marcha hasta la siguiente posada. Allí, se toman declaraciones juradas a cada testigo superviviente del ataque de los Mutantes, y los cuerpos son preparados para la llegada de un Augur, un sacerdote errante de Morr.

No se realizan esfuerzos por identificar a los desafortunados muertos. El Imperio es un lugar violento, y los guardias de caminos simplemente no disponen de recursos para localizar e informar a los familiares de cada viajero caído. En su lugar, el culto de Morr toma nota de los detalles de los muertos y luego los transmite al culto local de Verena, donde se archivan los registros de defunciones.

El cuerpo de Kastor Lieberung no lleva otra identificación que las dos cartas que ahora están en poder de los Personajes, por lo que probablemente será registrado como “desconocido”. Si algún Personaje, movido por su sentido de la honestidad, menciona las cartas, los guardias dejan claro que no tienen tiempo ni ganas para ocuparse de esas trivialidades: "¡Por Sigmar! Ocúpese de sus asuntos y no me moleste más".

Si los Personajes no han tomado medidas para disfrazar al doble de Kastor o desfigurar el cadáver de este, los guardias de caminos comentan la similitud con ironía ("¿Tu gemelo? Mala suerte, colega"), pero no toman ninguna otra medida. Todos han visto cosas más extrañas durante sus patrullas por los oscuros caminos del bosque Drakwald. Además, preguntar por dobles sospechosos no entra en sus funciones —ni en su salario.

El resto del trayecto hasta la siguiente posada transcurre sin incidentes. Los Personajes se cruzan con un par de diligencias con destino a Delberz, algunos trenes mercantes, un destacamento de caballería del Ejército Estatal, y cualquier otro encuentro que consideres apropiado. Cuando cae la noche, el carruaje finalmente llega a su destino: la última parada antes de Altdorf, la Posada Los Siete Radios.

Howls on the Wind.name: Aullidos en el viento
Howls on the Wind.text:
Mientras los Personajes se preguntan qué hacer a continuación, un grito bestial rasga el aire desde más allá de la curva, seguido de ruidos de ramas y arbustos siendo apartados al borde del camino. Algo viene rápidamente desde el bosque hacia ellos. Los aventureros deberían estar tensos en este momento y bien podrían disparar antes de reconocer a @UUID[Actor.uzWAvJDoBl0osDnW]{Hultz}, el cochero que fue visto por última vez siendo arrastrado por los caballos en pánico. Él corre de vuelta hacia el carruaje gritando: "¡Soy yo, Hultz! ¡No disparéis!" Si alguno de los personajes dispara, bien podría matarlo, ya que solo le quedan 2 Heridas tras ser arrastrado entre los árboles.

Viva o no Hultz, los personajes aún tienen el problema de los caballos desbocados y los gritos que se escuchan más adelante. Se debería animar a los personajes a investigar el origen de los gritos. Si no van voluntariamente, @UUID[Actor.goVesadmHWsl5E98]{Lady Isolde} les ordena hacerlo. Bajo ningún concepto ella o su séquito se alejarán del carruaje. Los cocheros, si siguen vivos, se ofrecen a buscar los caballos, pero son fácilmente persuadidos para esperar. No investigarán los gritos. @UUID[Actor.NTvkBP3VP4dtBqM0]{Ernst} también desea mantenerse al margen, alegando que aborrece la violencia.

A Friend In Need.name: A Friend In Need
A Friend In Need.text:
This encounter takes place at night on a lonely and deserted road, perhaps on the road to @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.ozE2DMCMK64eE5pD.JournalEntryPage.JSzzPHEHN8oOhd1z]{Helmgart}. For whatever reason, the Characters need to travel at night, despite the warnings of the staff at the last coaching inn. The road ahead is a terrible place, swarming with brigands and worse. It is even said to be haunted. The Characters may conclude that some of this could be true, but the innkeeper wanting them to stay because they will pay for room and board may have a great deal to do with all the warnings. Nevertheless, the Characters decide to press on: perhaps it is vital that they reach the next town by daybreak, or perhaps a group of road wardens is approaching the inn, and the Characters are keen to avoid them.

The first few miles after leaving the inn pass easily enough. There is still a fading light in the western sky, and they are only on the edge of the forest. As the road goes deeper into the forest, however, things begin to change. The darkness deepens, and can only be penetrated by @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.x0WMGwuQzReXcQrs]{Night Vision}. It begins to rain, a fine drizzle that works its way through even the stoutest clothing and soaks everyone to the skin. It’s impossible to light a torch, and lighting a lantern requires a successful Outdoor Survival or Dexterity Test, as the Characters’ tinder is very damp.

Above the soft hiss of the rain can be heard the noises of the forest’s nocturnal denizens going about their business. Somewhere in the darkness an owl screeches, and is answered by the snarl of a @UUID[Actor.8OyCmwhJL4YQFI0N]{Great Cat}. The Characters may now regret their bravado, but they have no choice but to press on; the next town is far closer than the inn they left.

Around midnight, the Characters come to a small shrine dedicated to Taal, the God of Wild Places. The shrine is a circular stone hut about 10 ft in diameter, with a conical thatched roof. An elk skull hangs over the doorway, and inside is a crude wooden statue of the god, about 5 ft high. There is room for five people to shelter in the shrine, in some discomfort. The roof leaks, but the shrine keeps the worst of the weather out, and the Characters can eat and perhaps snatch a couple of hours sleep. It’s impossible to light a fire in the shrine, since the Characters’ tinder-boxes and kindling are soaked.

Whether or not the Characters decide to shelter in the shrine, a strange thing will happen a few minutes after they arrive. Somewhere in the distance, a human voice is faintly heard. The words cannot be made out, but the voice is heavy with pain and misery. If the Characters have horses or any other animals with them, they will become nervous and skittish. The voice draws closer, and after several minutes the Characters make out a figure dragging itself along the road towards them.

The figure is indistinct and difficult to make out through the drizzle. It limps and staggers, as if on the verge of exhaustion, and yet it approaches surprisingly quickly. When the figure is within 10 yards, it can be seen to be a Human male. His clothes were once rich, but are now tattered, and he appears to be severely wounded. Blood oozes from dozens of small cuts all over his body. He raises his head to meet the Characters’ gaze, and a slash across his throat opens like a second mouth, sending blood cascading down his chest. One arm reaches out imploringly, and despite the fact that his legs have stopped moving, he continues to draw closer.

‘Help me,’ he moans. ‘Help me.’ As he approaches, the Characters realise with a shock that the trees and the road can still be seen through his insubstantial body.

At this point, the Characters should be subjected to the Ghost’s @Fear[2] Trait.

@UUID[Actor.rKQ6GURYq0iWHf7s]{Johann The Ghost}

If the Characters do not flee, the Ghost will not attempt to attack them. In a moaning voice, it will tell them that it was once Johann Gespenst, a merchant from the nearest town. While staying at the inn which the Characters recently left, @UUID[Actor.rKQ6GURYq0iWHf7s]{Johann} was murdered and robbed, and his body was brought into the forest on a cart and dumped by the roadside not far from the shrine. The Characters can free Johann from his miserable condition by collecting his bones and taking them to the town for decent burial. He will show the Characters where his body was dumped. His bones have been picked clean by wild animals and are scattered over an area about 10 yards in diameter.

The nearest town will have a graveyard, tended by a Priest of Morr. Depending on its size, it may also have a Mourners’ Guild, which undertakes all funeral arrangements. An individual grave and marker will cost @Pay[2gc]{2GCs}, while pauper’s burial in the unmarked mass grave will be free. On the night after the burial, Johann’s Ghost will appear to the Characters. He will still be an appalling sight, but free of the pain and desperation of his earlier appearance.

‘Thank you,’ he says. ‘May you never suffer as I have.’

If the Characters have his remains buried in the paupers’ grave, Johann will vanish, saying nothing more. If they have paid for a burial plot and headstone, he will tell them that it is still in his power to recompense them for what they have done for him. He will instruct them to contact his family in the town.

‘Tell them that you have helped me,’ he says. ‘Ask for my sister Greta, and tell her that I want her to give you a package, which she will find in a hidden compartment behind the second drawer on the right-hand side of my desk. If she questions you, mention the time when she was six years old, and I saved her when her horse had bolted. Then she will know that the message comes from me.’ With that, he will vanish.

If the Characters follow his instructions, the family will be puzzled, but will comply. In the package is a velvet pouch containing four rubies, worth @Credit[60gc mode=split]{15GCs each}.

Emmaretta.name: Emmaretta
Emmaretta.text:
@UUID[Actor.nU4A6C8LCx5SKf1O]{Emmaretta} can be encountered on any road in the Empire. As the Characters make their way along the road, they pass a young Human woman in her early 20s, travelling in the same direction. She is travelling alone; unusual in such dangerous forests. Her only possessions are a set of outdoor clothing, a small bag of dried meat, a short bow with a quiver of arrows slung over her back, and a pair of daggers hanging from her belt. 

@UUID[Actor.nU4A6C8LCx5SKf1O]{Emmaretta}   @UUID[Actor.8OyCmwhJL4YQFI0N]{Great Cat}

If any of the Characters speak to her she will answer courteously, giving her name and saying that she is a hunter heading for the nearest town. This may also be the Characters’ destination. She says that a friend is in trouble, and she is taking money to bail him out.

@UUID[Actor.nU4A6C8LCx5SKf1O]{Emmaretta} will quite happily travel with the Characters, and will be grateful if they offer her a lift. She cannot pay for a coach ride, as she needs all her money for her friend’s bail. If the Characters try to draw her into conversation during the course of the journey, and if she decides that she can trust them, she will explain that it is her lover Klaus who has been imprisoned. She will say that she needs to bail him out before a certain date: a successful Average (+20) Lore (Astronomy) or (Astrology) Test reveals that Mannslieb is full that night.

What @UUID[Actor.nU4A6C8LCx5SKf1O]{Emmaretta} says about her journey is true, but she neglects to mention an important detail: both she and her lover are Werecats. Klaus has not yet learned to control his condition. If he is still in jail when Mannslieb becomes full, he will be seen changing, and will almost certainly be killed by the guards.

Emmaretta is travelling in the company of two of the great @UUID[Actor.8OyCmwhJL4YQFI0N]{Wild Cats} of the Old World. They are trailing her from the forest, and will attack if she is threatened in any way. She is anxious to avoid trouble, and will call them off almost immediately, warning the Characters that it would be best to leave her alone and go on their way. If she is hard pressed, she will adopt her Cat form and run off into the forest with her two travelling companions. She will only stand and fight if the money she is carrying is stolen. It’s needed for Klaus’s bail, and Emmaretta will use any means at her disposal to get it back.

If @UUID[Actor.nU4A6C8LCx5SKf1O]{Emmaretta} decides to travel with the Characters, her two Great Cats will continue to shadow her from the forest. They move stealthily, so that any character must make an Hard (–20) Perception Test to spot them. Even then, all that will be seen will be a movement in the undergrowth. The Great Cats wait in the forest while she goes into the town. Once she has bailed Klaus out, the Werecats head for the forest, assume Cat form, and travel back to their home with their two companions.

This encounter can be used to add to an adventure in a number of ways. When @UUID[Actor.nU4A6C8LCx5SKf1O]{Emmaretta} arrives at the town, a corrupt Watchman might take her money and then deny having received it, leading to her asking the Characters to get Klaus out of jail as a favour. The party might be attacked by Bandits, in which case she will fight alongside the Characters, and her two Great Cats will come to their aid, melting back into the forest when the fight is over. If she is questioned about the Great Cats, Emmaretta will simply answer: ‘I grew up in the forest. I suppose I’ve made some unusual friends.’ One of the other NPC travellers might fall foul of the Cats by pestering her or trying to steal her money. You should use your imagination to get the most out of the encounter.

Werecats? Really?

This encounter, like all of The Enemy Within, has close ties to the history of Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay. We've presented it here as the encoutner was written in the 1980s, but since that time the identity of the Old World and it's denizens has been considerably refined. For better or worse, Werecats have not remained with us to the present day. If you'd like to update this encounter to bring it in line with the Old World as we know it today, consider making Emerretta and her partner Werewolves. She may be accompanied by two large wolves, rather than wildcats. Alternatively, you might like to keep the wildcats, but have Emaretta and Klaus suffering the effects of a terrible curse wrought on them by a malign magus - something which would be in fitting with the themes of mutation and change that permeate The Enemy Within.

On the Road.name: On the Road
On the Road.text:
These two short encounters can be used when the Characters are travelling by road. Both are roleplay encounters requiring thought and observation rather than blades and bows.

@UUID[.Fg0aOxVwqkFWsBKv]{Emmaretta}

@UUID[.itIjEiNtkkGBZRql]{A Friend In Need}

Down the years, a lot of excellent short adventures have been written for WFRP, appearing in White Dwarf magazine during the 1980s, and in various collections and anthologies. Over the following pages, three of the best are presented to be dropped into the Enemy in Shadows or played on their own.

On the Road was one of the first adventures to be published for WFRP, appearing in White Dwarf 85 in February 1987. These two road encounters can open out into short adventures, and enliven any road journey.

Mounted Combat.name: Mounted Combat
Mounted Combat.text:
Given the Old World’s penchant for violence, at some point someone will take umbrage with a Character mounted on an animal, or inside a vehicle. These rules are intended to expand upon those presented on @UUID[JournalEntry.GHueUtHKzlhvsd8L.JournalEntryPage.hypkj7MNgpyfnZMJ]{Mounted Combat}.

Hit Locations

Whilst the hit locations table in Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay works well for bipedal creatures, it doesn’t account for quadrupedal animals like horses and dogs, and definitely doesn’t do for pulled, drawn, or carried vehicles. As with normal hit locations, reverse the roll to hit, and consult the following tables.

You can change an Actor's hit location table in the Actor Configuration menu accessed at the top of the sheet.

Attacks on Quadrupeds

RollLocation
01-16Head
17-56Body
57-67Front Left Leg
68-78Front Right Leg
79-89Back Left Leg
90-00Back Right Leg

Some results on this table may be impractical or bizarre in practice, due to the way an animal is facing, or the size difference between the animal and the attacker. In these instances, treat any impractical results as a Body hit, instead.

Example: Harbull is staring down a terrifying Chaos Knight mounted on a nightmarish steed, which is bounding towards him. He attempts to stop the beast in its tracks with his sling, but rolls an 84 for hit location: Back Left Leg. Whilst it’s possible Harbull’s shot hits such an unlikely location, the GM decides such a shot is impractical, and rules that the Body was hit instead.

Caring for Injured Animals

Animal Care is the primary Skill used to treat sick or wounded animals, but magic and herbal preparations can be used as well. Healing spells and miracles work just as well on animals as they do on Humans, Elves, and the like.

If you wish, an appropriate deity such as Taal might grant the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.C92dpJPRYpkZFsGu]{Blessing of Healing} to an animal where this would not normally be available. Healing Miracles granted to animals by Taal or another deity are similar to the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.NcH9OhleJFfaUdon.JournalEntryPage.saPG89YXGANoIJBz#miracles-of-shallya]{miracles of Shallya}.

The @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.sLomXnc8R8518cWN.JournalEntryPage.4CBQ1HlTC7lj9bFy]{drugs, poisons}, @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.sLomXnc8R8518cWN.JournalEntryPage.PYiffieXenZHBUAU]{herbs, and draughts} listed in the WFRP rulebook mostly work on animals as they do on other Characters. However, some plants that are harmless, even delicious, to Humans are poisonous to animals. Characters who have the relevant Animal Care Skill in addition to the Herbalist and/or Apothecary Skills needed to gather and prepare remedies know the ingredients to avoid, and only include something dangerous in a preparation on an Astounding Failure. Other Characters make such a mistake on a normal Failure. 

An animal that ingests food or medicine that is poisonous to it must succeed on a Challenging (+0) Endurance Test or take one or more @Condition[Poisoned] Conditions.

move Over!

Sometimes the grass is greener on the other side, and you need to move from one vehicle or mount to another without taking the time to stop. Leaping on to a moving vehicle requires a Challenging (+0) Athletics Test. If the Character fails they miss their target, suffering a 2-yard fall. Leaping on to a moving mount without a rider requires the same Test, followed by a Challenging (+0) Ride Test if the mount has the Skittish Trait. If you attempt to leap on to a mount that has a rider, you must also make an Opposed Ride Test against the current rider — the winner remains on the mount and the loser is thrown off, suffering a 2-yard fall.

These rules assume that you are jumping from a mount or vehicle that has matched speeds with your target. Attempting either of these manoeuvres from a stationary position increases the difficulty penalty by −20.

Attacks on Vehicles

Given a vehicle cannot dodge or move of its own accord, any melee attack made against a stationary vehicle automatically hits. If the vehicle is moving, or a Character wishes to attack a specific, difficult-to-hit spot, count the attack as a called shot at –20. If the driver of a moving vehicle is attacked in melee, resolve this as an Opposed Melee Test, but the driver may use an appropriate Drive Skill if they wish.

Ranged attacks against vehicles are resolved as normal; most vehicles are Large targets (+20) and quite easy to hit. However, bullets, arrows, and bolts typically do no appreciable damage to the wood and canvas construction of most vehicles. At the GM’s discretion, called shots against fragile components such as the vehicle’s harness may still trigger one of the special effects, described below.

Vehicles have a Toughness Characteristic, from which a Toughness Bonus may be determined, and a number of Wounds, which function exactly the same as any other target in Combat. Vehicles cannot suffer Critical Wounds, but if a called shot to one of the locations below scores a Critical, then the described effect occurs. Furthermore, if the vehicle is in motion when a Critical Hit is suffered, or its wounds are reduced to 0, the driver must make a Difficult (-20) Drive Test or roll for a @Table[vehiclemishap]{Vehicle Mishap}.

Harness

The shafts are shattered, the traces cut, or the team is separated from the vehicle in some other way. Treat this as an Out of Control vehicle mishap.

Wheels

A wheel breaks or falls off, requiring repairs before the vehicle can proceed any further. A two-wheeled vehicle tips over, shedding its load and dumping any passengers on to the ground in a 1-yard fall.

Seating/Cargo Area

The attack hits the part of the vehicle where people sit or where goods are stored, smashing a sizeable hole in the vehicle. Half the attack’s Damage is also inflicted on a random item of cargo or passenger inside the vehicle. A chair or litter has one of the carrying poles broken, drops to the ground, and is immobilized.

Repairing Vehicles

Damage to a vehicle can be repaired permanently on a successful Trade skill Test, provided that materials, tools, and working facilities are available.

Any Character can attempt repairs using Trade (Carpenter) or similar Skills as the GM deems appropriate. Each repair takes one hour and restores ([[/r 1d10]] + SL) Damage points.

Most coaching inns have a blacksmith in residence or nearby who can replace cast shoes. Such a trader will also have enough skill in carpentry to patch up a vehicle so that it can reach a nearby town, where a more skilled cartwright or coachmaker can be found. Any Character can attempt repairs using Trade (Carpenter) or similar Skills as the GM deems appropriate. Each repair takes one hour and restores ([[/r 1d10]] + SL) Damage points.

Driving And Riding.name: Driving And Riding
Driving And Riding.text:
Driving the Old World’s vehicles and keeping control of its mounts pose unique challenges. The @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.6zOdTLv3YeYeJ4hR.JournalEntryPage.uLPWAFSfT5Vf1zZl]{Drive} Skill and the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.6zOdTLv3YeYeJ4hR.JournalEntryPage.QQukmSP68cF8MzJe]{Ride} Skill} are used for these Tests. Under most circumstances, a Character can operate a vehicle or mount without a Test. However, obstacles and adverse conditions may prompt a Drive or Ride Test.

This chapter includes a range of mishaps to inflict upon travellers. These can be used instead of the @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.6zOdTLv3YeYeJ4hR.JournalEntryPage.uLPWAFSfT5Vf1zZl]{Drive} rules ta add colour and variety.

Travel Speed

The speed of a vehicle or mount along a road depends on its final Movement rate, when all Encumbrance and other factors have been taken into account. Each point of Movement equals one mile per hour at walking pace, 1.5 miles per hour at a trot, and 2 miles per hour at a canter. Hazards and bad weather may slow the pace of any travel.

A mount can travel at a Walk for up to 12 hours without a rest, then an hour’s pause and a drink of water restores its freshness for a number of hours equal to its Toughness Bonus. This is usually when bandits attack. 

Faster speeds can only be maintained for a limited time. Animals may Trot for their Toughness Bonus in hours, or may Canter (run) for half their Toughness Bonus in hours.

For every hour that the animal is pushed beyond its normal travel endurance, it gains a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition and must make a Challenging (+0) Endurance Test. Failure gives the animal another Fatigued condition and requires a roll on the @Table[ridingmishap]{Riding Mishap Table}. When the number of @Condition[Fatigued] Conditions exceeds the animal’s Toughness Bonus, the animal collapses, gaining both @Condition[Stunned] and @Condition[Prone] Conditions. A final Challenging (+0) Endurance Test is made, without any modifiers; failure indicates the poor creature has been driven to the point of death.

Broken Tack

A torn saddle strap, a shredded harness or a lost stirrup — some part of your mount’s tack has been damaged, making travel more difficult. The rider must make a Difficult (–10) Ride Test or @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.bdfiyhEYtKs7irqc#falling]{fall off} (a distance of 2 yards). Until the tack is repaired, all future Ride Tests suffer a –20 penalty.

Cast Shoe

The animal loses a shoe. The rider must make a Difficult (–10) Ride Test or @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.bdfiyhEYtKs7irqc#falling]{fall off} (a distance of 2 yards). The animal must move at a Walk until the shoe has been replaced by a farrier. Forcing the animal to move faster cause it to become @UUID[.lLe63oYqpVSctopI#lame]{Lame}.

Lame

The animal cannot move faster than half its Walk speed, cannot be ridden or carry packs, and cannot pull a load. Attempting to bring the animal any further on a journey using the @UUID[JournalEntry.1tdhntCNqK83TS94]{Travel rules} increases the journey length by 1 Stage. Any attempt to do any of these things costs the animal [[/r 1d10]] Wounds, regardless of Toughness Bonus. On a roll of 8+, the animal must make a Challenging (+0) Endurance Test or suffer a @Table[critleg]{Critical Wound} to its legs.

Broken Leg

The animal suffers a @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.items.2iult41Jehz0F1O8]{Broken Bone (Major)} on its leg, and becomes immobile. If the broken bone ever heals, the animal’s Movement is reduced by half. Usually, when a horse or similar breaks a leg, there is little hope of it surviving.

Being Dragged

Falling from the saddle is bad enough — the equivalent of 2 yards on to the ground — but in the Old World things can always go from bad to worse very quickly. Every rider dreads being thrown from the saddle with one foot still caught in the stirrup, and then dragged helplessly along a rocky road by a panicking mount.

When a Character falls from a mount because of an Astounding Failure, they must make a Challenging (+0) Dodge Test. Failure indicates that the unfortunate individual has been caught with one foot still in a stirrup. If the mount is standing still, the fallen rider can try to free the tangled foot from the stirrup by making an Extended Challenging (+0) Athletics Test requiring 3 Success Levels. With the final success, the rider has managed to bend, stretch, and twist into a position where both hands can reach the foot and stirrup.

If the mount is moving, a rider is nearly helpless. The rider is @Condition[Prone] and @Condition[Entangled], and suffers one Damage each turn if the mount is walking, or the mount’s Movement characteristic in damage each round if it is troting or cantering. There is no Strength Test to break the entanglement, but if the rider has a sharp weapon on hand (and did not drop or lose it in the fall) a successful Very Hard (–30) Weapon Skill Test cuts through the stirrup strap.

Vehicles of the Empire

Vehicle Speeds

An animal pulling a cart, wagon, coach, or other vehicle moves more slowly than one that is running free or carrying a rider. Animals pulling a vehicle may only Walk or Trot safely. Operators carrying, pushing, or pulling a vehicle may only Walk.

An animal may be forced to move at a Run whilst pulling a vehicle. The driver must make a Challenging (+0) Drive Test every mile, with a penalty of –10 per mile already travelled while at a Run. A failure slows the animals to a Walk, and each animal must make a successful Challenging (+0) Endurance Test or gain a @Condition[Fatigued] Condition.

An Astounding Failure (–6 SL) by the driver on the Drive Test requires a roll on the @Table[vehiclemishap]{Vehicle Mishap} Table. An Impressive or worse failure on any an animal’s Endurance Test imposes an additional @Condition[Fatigued] Condition, and an Astounding Failure costs the beast [[/r 1d10]] Wounds in addition (modified by Toughness Bonus, to a minimum of 1).

Many of these mishaps result in a vehicle Crashing if it is moving faster than Walking speed. Occupants of Crashing vehicles suffer [[/r 2d10]] Wounds modified by Toughness Bonus and Armour Points minimum 1. Crashed vehicles must be repaired by someone with an appropriate Trade Skill, such as Trade (Carpenter) or Trade (Cartwright). (See @UUID[.hypkj7MNgpyfnZMJ#repairing-vehicles]{Repairing Vehicles}). Spare wheels can be installed by anyone with a Drive Test or with an appropriate Trade Test.

Out of Control!

By some mischance, the reins break and the driver has no way of steering the vehicle, speeding up, or slowing down. If the driver does not take some action to stop the vehicle, it may collide with something! If the vehicle was moving at walking speed and is not brought under control in [[/r 1d10]] Rounds, it strikes something and becomes Damaged. If it was moving faster than walking speed, it Crashes instead.

This mishap may also occur if the driver is killed or otherwise prevented from steering the vehicle.

Damaged

Something vital is damaged: a wheel cracks, the axle warps, or a similar problem occurs. The vehicle may continue at a walking speed only until repaired by someone with an appropriate Trade Skill, such as Trade (Carpenter) or Trade (Cartwright). If driven faster, the vehicle becomes Broken after [[/r 1d10]] Rounds.

Broken

Something vital breaks: a harness, wheel, or axle. If the vehicle is pulled by a team of animals, they may have become untied from the vehicle: the driver must make a successful Challenging (+0) Athletics Test in order to let go of the reins and avoid being pulled out of the driver’s seat. A failure indicates a @UUID[Compendium.wfrp4e-core.journals.NS3YGlJQxwTggjRX.JournalEntryPage.bdfiyhEYtKs7irqc#falling]{Fall} and @UUID[.lLe63oYqpVSctopI#being-dragged]{Being Dragged}.

The vehicle suffers [[/r 1d10]] Damage immediately, modified by Toughness Bonus minimum 1. The vehicle may not be driven further until repaired with an appropriate Trade Skill, such as Trade (Carpenter) or Trade (Cartwright). Anyone in the vehicle suffers 1 Wound immediately, unmodified by Toughness Bonus or Armour Points.If the vehicle was moving faster than walking speed, treat this result as a Crash instead.

Crash!

The vehicle collides with something at speed. Occupants of Crashing vehicles suffer [[/r 2d10]] Wounds modified by Toughness Bonus and Armour Points minimum 1. The vehicle suffers [[/r 2d10]] Damage immediately, modified by Toughness Bonus, minimum 1. Crashed vehicles must be repaired by someone with an appropriate Trade Skill, such as Trade (Carpenter) or Trade (Cartwright) before they can be driven again.

The Thunder Of Black Wheels

Every corner of the Empire has its own tales of the Black Coaches — terrible two-horse contraptions seen travelling at breakneck speeds down the Emperor’s roads in the dead of night. Whilst dismissed as little more than peasant foolishness, Road Captain Sigrid Wachsam has been tracking sightings for the past year, and is convinced of their authenticity. Captain Wachsam has identified a stretch of road not far from Castle Grauenburg with frequent occurrences, and wants to hire someone outside the road wardens to investigate.

Mounts and Vehicles.name: Mounts and Vehicles
Mounts and Vehicles.text:
Given the precarious nature of the roads, and the sheer distance involved when moving between the great cities and towns of the Empire, it is no surprise that few travellers choose to go on foot. Riding beasts, draught animals, lumbering carts, and thundering coaches are a common sight along the highways and backroads between the pinpricks of civilisation.
